title: Greater_than_or_equal
markdown:
# Greater than or equal (>=)

 The **greater than or equal (`>=`)** operator returns `true` if the left operand is greater than or equal to the right operand, and `false` otherwise.

## [Try it](#try%5Fit)

## [Syntax](#syntax)

```
x >= y

```

## [Description](#description)

The operands are compared using the same algorithm as the [Less than](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Less%5Fthan) operator, with the result negated. `x >= y` is generally equivalent to `!(x < y)`, except for two cases where `x >= y` and `x < y` are both `false`:

* If one of the operands gets converted to a BigInt, while the other gets converted to a string that cannot be converted to a BigInt value (it throws a [syntax error](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Invalid%5FBigInt%5Fsyntax) when passed to [BigInt()](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global%5FObjects/BigInt/BigInt)).
* If one of the operands gets converted to `NaN`. (For example, strings that cannot be converted to numbers, or `undefined`.)

`x >= y` is generally equivalent to `x > y || x == y`, except for a few cases:

* When one of `x` or `y` is `null`, and the other is something that's not `null` and becomes 0 when [coerced to numeric](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Data%5Fstructures#numeric%5Fcoercion) (including `0`, `0n`, `false`, `""`, `"0"`, `new Date(0)`, etc.): `x >= y` is `true`, while `x > y || x == y` is `false`.
* When one of `x` or `y` is `undefined`, and the other is one of `null` or `undefined`: `x >= y` is `false`, while `x == y` is `true`.
* When `x` and `y` are the same object that becomes `NaN` after the first step of [Less than](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Less%5Fthan) (such as `new Date(NaN)`): `x >= y` is `false`, while `x == y` is `true`.
* When `x` and `y` are different objects that become the same value after the first step of [Less than](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Less%5Fthan): `x >= y` is `true`, while `x > y || x == y` is `false`.

## [Examples](#examples)

### [String to string comparison](#string%5Fto%5Fstring%5Fcomparison)

```
"a" >= "b"; // false
"a" >= "a"; // true
"a" >= "3"; // true

```

### [String to number comparison](#string%5Fto%5Fnumber%5Fcomparison)

```
"5" >= 3; // true
"3" >= 3; // true
"3" >= 5; // false

"hello" >= 5; // false
5 >= "hello"; // false

```

### [Number to Number comparison](#number%5Fto%5Fnumber%5Fcomparison)

```
5 >= 3; // true
3 >= 3; // true
3 >= 5; // false

```

### [Number to BigInt comparison](#number%5Fto%5Fbigint%5Fcomparison)

```
5n >= 3; // true
3 >= 3n; // true
3 >= 5n; // false

```

### [Comparing Boolean, null, undefined, NaN](#comparing%5Fboolean%5Fnull%5Fundefined%5Fnan)

```
true >= false; // true
true >= true; // true
false >= true; // false

true >= 0; // true
true >= 1; // true

null >= 0; // true
1 >= null; // true

undefined >= 3; // false
3 >= undefined; // false

3 >= NaN; // false
NaN >= 3; // false

```

## [Specifications](#specifications)

| Specification                                                                                                                                                     |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| [ECMAScript Language Specification  \# sec-relational-operators](https://tc39.es/ecma262/multipage/ecmascript-language-expressions.html#sec-relational-operators) |

## [Browser compatibility](#browser%5Fcompatibility)

BCD tables only load in the browser
